awd_titl_txt: MCA-PGR: Phylogeny-Guided Biochemical Genomics to Elucidate the Tyrosine-Derived Lignin Metabolic Network of Grasses
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants produce a variety of chemical compounds that are essential for making cells and the entire organism.  One of these compounds, lignin, gives physical strength and supports water transport in plants.  It is beneficial to generate bioenergy plants with less lignin because lignin impedes the production of bioethanol. However, lowering lignin production may negatively impact plant growth. This research will address this fundamental issue by studying how essential compounds such as lignin are synthesized and how the underlying processes evolved in different plants.  Specifically, this project seeks to understand the genes and pathways responsible for making lignin in grasses, which are major sources of food and bioenergy production. Because grasses have a unique pathway for making lignin that is not found in other plants, understanding the evolution of this grass-specific lignin pathway will provide better strategies to improve grasses for efficient production of food and energy.  To increase the awareness of the importance of plant-derived compounds and to train next generations of scientists, this project will conduct K-12 outreach activities called "Pigment Art+."  This will be specifically focused on schools from communities that are underrepresented in science. The scientific and educational outcomes of this project will have broad impacts for both research and society through improved understanding of how essential compounds, such as lignin, are made in plants. 

Primary metabolites, such as proteins and cell walls, directly impact yield, quality, and performance of crops. This research will explore primary metabolic diversity to uncover major evolutionary innovations of plant metabolism and to provide novel tools and strategies to rationally optimize these core metabolic processes in plants. A primary cell wall component, lignin, and other phenolic compounds are produced through a complex network of the aromatic amino acid and phenylpropanoid pathways and usually synthesized from L-phenylalanine. Uniquely, grasses synthesize lignin additionally from L-tyrosine. This research aims to elucidate biochemical and genetic basis of this unique diversification of primary metabolism, the tyrosine-derived lignin biosynthetic pathway. Utilizing the wealth of genome/transcriptome data from grass and non-grass monocots, this project will employ "phylogeny-guided" biochemical and genomic analyses to dissect the tyrosine-derived lignin biosynthetic pathways and their evolutionary history. Aim 1) will determine the evolutionary timing of the emergence of the tyrosine-lignin pathway through activity screening of key enzymes across monocots. Aim 2) will define molecular basis of the evolution of the tyrosine-derived lignin pathway through phylogeny-guided structure-function analyses of these enzymes. Aim 3) will further identify genes and enzymes that co-evolved and reshaped the overall tyrosine-lignin biosynthetic network. Aim 4) will elucidate potential functionalization of key enzymes involved in the tyrosine-lignin biosynthetic network. This study will establish a multidisciplinary approach of phylogeny-guided biochemical genomics, which allows us to investigate evolutionary history of complex traits, such as primary metabolic diversity, that occurred in multiple loci over a long evolutionary time scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Phylogeny-Guided Biochemical Genomics to Elucidate the Tyrosine-Derived Lignin Metabolic Network of Grasses

Plants utilize atmospheric CO2 and sunlight energy to produce a wide variety of organic molecules, such as proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, and natural products, including diverse phenolic compounds. These compounds derived from plants provide our food, feed, fuel, fibers, medicine, and materials. Therefore, enhancing their production is crucial for building a sustainable economy and society while mitigating climate change. However, these metabolites are dispensable cellular components of plants, directly impacting plant growth and development. Consequently, their biosynthetic pathways, especially those linked to the primary metabolic network, are evolutionarily constrained and typically conserved throughout the plant kingdom, making them challenging to manipulate.

To tackle this challenge, this project established a novel approach to dissect complex plant metabolic networks by investigating when and how specific pathways within these networks evolved over the course of evolutionary history. Specifically, the project focused on the tyrosine-derived lignin metabolic network uniquely present in grasses, such as maize, rice, and sorghum, which provide major dietary calories and bioenergy production. The project utilized the wealth of emerging plant genomes for phylogenomic and gene network analyses, which further guided enzyme biochemistry and metabolomics analyses across key plant groups. This so-called "phylogeny-guided biochemical genomics" approach unveiled the stepwise evolution of the grass lignin metabolic network at a macroevolutionary scale. It also revealed the genomic and molecular basis of new genes and enzymes, such as phenylalanine/tyrosine ammonia lyase (PTAL), that uniquely evolved in grasses and shaped the tyrosine-derived lignin metabolic network. The regulation of the upstream aromatic amino acid biosynthesis was also altered in grasses to accommodate the dual entry pathways to phenylpropanoid and lignin biosynthesis. The findings not only shed light on the evolution of essential plant metabolic networks but also offer novel technologies and strategies for rational engineering of primary metabolism to sustainably produce essential amino acids and a wide range of phenolic compounds using plants. Therefore, the outcomes of this project have a potential to improve nutritional values and biomass quality of grasses and other agricultural and bioenergy crops.

As a part of broader impact activity, the project team undertook a range of outreach and educational activities to promote the importance of plant natural products and to train next generations of scientists and citizens who can exploit tremendous potential of plant metabolic diversity. In-person outreach events, like the "Pigment-Art", "Odyssey of Plants", and "Build-a-Plant," which engaged K-12 students in hands-on activities related to plant chemistry and biology. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the team adapted by participating in virtual events such as online UW's 2021 Darwin Day and Science Expeditions, creating video contents to reach a wider audience. The team also collaborated with undergraduate students and developed a chemotaxonomy database as a novel teaching and research tool to facilitate the study of plant metabolic diversity and evolution. Additionally, the PI designed a new course, "Harnessing Plant Chemistry for a Sustainable Future," targeting incoming students and using various teaching methods to discuss the significance of plant chemistry in building a sustainable society. These activities not only raised awareness among broader audiences but also provided valuable learning experiences for postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates in communicating the importance of plant metabolic diversity in our society.
